deliberation: Checked for metaphors, personifications, idioms, and stock judgment formulas. The verse is mainly narrative, but the phrase 'from small to great' (מִקָּטֹן וְעַד־גָּדוֹל) functions as a merism expressing totality. No other figurative expressions detected.

instances.english_text: from small to great
target: all the people present regardless of rank
vehicle: the span from the smallest individual to the greatest
ground: using the extremes to imply everyone in between
posture: describing the scope of those approaching Jeremiah
instances.explanation: This is a merism: the extremes 'small' and 'great' stand for the whole group, indicating that people of every status came.

deliberation: Considered the remnant language and numerical contrast, which appear literal. The request formula 'may our supplication fall before you' is idiomatic and metaphorical, picturing a plea as a physical object falling at someone's feet.

instances.english_text: Let our plea fall before you
vehicle: an object falling down in front of someone
ground: coming under someone's gaze and control as something laid at their feet
posture: respectful, deferential address to a prophetic figure
instances.explanation: Their request is pictured as something that 'falls' before Jeremiah, a common Hebrew idiom in which a plea is conceptualized as a tangible object placed at someone's feet for judgment.

deliberation: Looked for metaphors and idioms. The key phrase 'the way in which we shall walk' uses the spatial idea of a road and walking for the abstract notion of life conduct and decisions.

instances.english_text: the way in which we should walk
target: the community's future course of action
vehicle: a road or path on which one walks
ground: both a path and a life-course have direction, alternatives, and outcomes depending on which way one goes
instances.explanation: The verse uses the common biblical metaphor of 'way' and 'walking' for how one lives and acts, asking God to indicate the right path of behavior.

deliberation: Most of the verse is literal description of prayer and reporting. The phrase 'I will not withhold from you a word/anything' treats information as an object that can be physically held back, functioning as an idiomatic metaphor.

instances.english_text: I will withhold nothing from you
target: the full content of God's message Jeremiah will communicate
vehicle: physically holding back an item from someone
ground: both physical withholding and partial disclosure deny the recipient full access
instances.explanation: Jeremiah depicts God's words as if they were objects that could be kept back in the hand; promising not to 'withhold' any is an idiomatic metaphor for full disclosure.

deliberation: Examined the oath formula. The core figurative element is their request that YHWH be 'a witness' concerning them, casting God in the human legal role of courtroom witness as a way to sanction their promise.

instances.hebrew_text: יְהִי יְהוָה בָּנוּ לְעֵד אֱמֶת וְנֶאֱמָן
instances.english_text: Let the LORD be a true and faithful witness against us
target: God's role in holding them accountable to their oath
vehicle: a human witness in a court case
ground: both a courtroom witness and God in this role observe, attest to truth, and can bring consequences for perjury
instances.explanation: They metaphorically cast YHWH as a legal witness in a lawsuit, a standard covenant idiom that underscores the seriousness and enforceability of their promise.

deliberation: Reviewed for multiple expressions. The key phrase 'whether good or bad' is a merism for the full range of possible instructions or outcomes. The rest ('it may go well with us') is conventional but not strongly figurative here.

instances.english_text: whether it is pleasant or unpleasant / whether good or bad
target: the full range of what God might command them
vehicle: the two opposite evaluations good and bad
ground: naming both extremes implies everything in between
instances.explanation: This is a merism: by vowing obedience if the word is 'good' or 'bad', they claim readiness to accept any outcome at all.

deliberation: Considered whether the phrase 'the word of YHWH came' is purely formulaic or still figurative. It personifies the 'word' as an agent that arrives, and uses 'word' metonymically for the whole revelatory event.

instances.english_text: the word of the LORD came to Jeremiah
target: God's act of revealing His message to Jeremiah
vehicle: a spoken word that moves from speaker to hearer
ground: both a spoken word and a revelation originate with a speaker and arrive at a recipient as a distinct communication
instances.explanation: The expression treats 'the word' as if it were a moving entity that comes to Jeremiah, and 'word' stands metonymically for the entire revelation given to the prophet.

deliberation: Again examined for figurative range markers. As in v.1, 'from small to great' is a merism for the whole group; the rest is straightforward narration.

instances.english_text: from small to great
vehicle: the spectrum from the smallest to the greatest
range of social rank or importance
ground: extremes used to signal everyone in between
posture: emphasizing that the message is addressed to everyone
instances.explanation: The phrase is a merism, using opposite ends of a spectrum to signify that all levels of the community were included.

deliberation: Most of the verse is literal reporting of speech. The phrase 'to cause your supplication to fall before Him' repeats the petition metaphor from v.2, treating prayer as an object dropped at God's feet.

instances.english_text: to present your supplication before Him (lit. to cause your supplication to fall before Him)
target: the act of interceding with God on behalf of the people
vehicle: causing an object to fall in front of someone
ground: placing something at another's feet for consideration parallels presenting a plea for judgment or mercy
yielding control of the matter to another
instances.explanation: The Hebrew idiom pictures their supplication as a thing that 'falls' before God's presence, a metaphor for placing one's cause under His scrutiny.

deliberation: Here the oracle uses Jeremiah's characteristic restoration metaphors: (1) building/not tearing down and (2) planting/not uprooting, both applied to the people as if they were a structure or a planting. These are distinct but parallel metaphors.

instances.english_text: I will build you and not overthrow
target: the restoration and strengthening of the remnant of Judah
vehicle: constructing or tearing down a building
ground: both a building and a community can be made stable or demolished
posture: promising positive reversal of previous judgment
instances.explanation: The people are portrayed as a house or structure that God can build up or tear down; here He promises to build, not demolish, signaling restoration.

instances.english_text: I will plant you and not uproot
target: the people dwelling securely in their land
vehicle: a plant that is planted firmly or torn up by the roots
ground: both plants and peoples can be firmly established or removed from their place
posture: assuring lasting settlement if they obey
instances.explanation: Judah is likened to a plant that God can either plant to grow or uproot to destroy; the metaphor conveys the promise of secure re-establishment in the land.

deliberation: The main content is literally about fear of the king of Babylon and divine protection. The notable figurative expression is 'rescue you from his hand,' where 'hand' stands metonymically for power and control.

instances.english_text: to rescue you from his hand
target: freedom from the king of Babylon's control
vehicle: a physical hand that grasps and holds
ground: both a hand that grabs and a ruler's authority exert controlling power over others
capacity to seize, hold, and release
instances.explanation: The king's 'hand' stands for his power and control, a common metonymy where the limb symbolizes the agent's might.

deliberation: Reviewed for metaphors and idioms. The phrase 'I will give you mercies' treats compassion as something that can be 'given' like a concrete object, an idiomatic way to describe God producing a favorable disposition in others.

instances.english_text: I will grant you mercy
target: the favorable attitude others will have toward Judah
vehicle: tangible 'mercies' handed over as a gift
ground: both giving an object and causing someone to feel mercy involve bestowing something beneficial on another
posture: assuring them of divinely arranged favor
instances.explanation: Compassion is conceptualized as a bestowable thing that God can 'give' to them, an idiomatic metaphor where the abstract attitude stands metonymically for the concrete effects of favor.

deliberation: This verse straightforwardly reports their possible refusal to stay in the land and defines that as not listening to God's voice. The 'voice' expression becomes more clearly figurative in v.21; here the focus is on the basic act of disobedience. I treat this verse as functionally literal within the prophetic idiom.

Checked 'see war,' 'hear the sound of the horn,' and 'hunger for bread.' In context these are literal expectations about military conflict and famine, not stylized metaphors. No distinct figurative expressions were identified beyond normal descriptive language.
Searched for idioms and metaphors. The notable idiom is 'set your faces to go to Egypt,' which uses physical orientation of the face as a metaphor for determined intention.

instances.english_text: If you set your faces to go to Egypt
target: their fixed determination to migrate to Egypt
vehicle: turning and setting one's face toward a destination
ground: both the direction of one's face and one's inner resolve indicate where one is heading
focus and commitment to a course
posture: warning them against this settled resolve
instances.explanation: The idiom uses the physical act of setting the face toward a direction as a metaphor for firm inner decision and orientation of the will.

deliberation: Identified two vivid judgment images: (1) 'the sword will overtake you' and (2) 'the famine will cling/follow after you.' Both personify calamities as pursuing agents, and 'sword' operates as metonymy for warfare.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהָיְתָה הַחֶרֶב אֲשֶׁר אַתֶּם יְרֵאִים מִמֶּנָּה שָׁם תַּשִּׂיג אֶתְכֶם
instances.english_text: the sword that you fear shall overtake you there
target: the violent military judgment awaiting them in Egypt
vehicle: a sword pursuing and catching someone
ground: both a chasing enemy and 'the sword' here represent relentless, inescapable lethal threat
posture: intensely warning them of inescapable war
instances.explanation: The 'sword' stands metonymically for warfare and is personified as an agent that actively chases and overtakes them, conveying the inevitability of violent judgment.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהָרָעָב אֲשֶׁר־אַתֶּם דֹּאֲגִים מִמֶּנּוּ שָׁם יִדְבַּק אַחֲרֵיכֶם
instances.english_text: and the famine you worry over shall follow at your heels (cling after you) there
target: the severe lack of food that will strike them
vehicle: a pursuer who sticks closely behind someone
ground: both a clinging follower and ongoing famine remain close and inescapable
posture: amplifying the threat beyond mere war
instances.explanation: Famine is personified as a pursuer that 'clings' behind them, and functions metonymically for all the miseries of want that will relentlessly follow them into Egypt.

deliberation: Detected (1) the idiom 'set their faces to go to Egypt' again, and (2) the triad 'sword, famine, and pestilence' functioning as a stock synecdoche for comprehensive judgment, not just a random list of three discrete causes of death.

instances.english_text: who have set their faces to go to Egypt
target: their determined choice to relocate to Egypt
vehicle: deliberately setting one's face toward a destination
ground: both the direction of the face and decision of the will indicate commitment to a given course
posture: characterizing that decision as deliberate and culpable
instances.explanation: As in v.15, the idiom uses the orientation of the face as a metaphor for the orientation of the will toward Egypt.

instances.english_text: they shall die by the sword, by famine, and by pestilence
target: the totality of lethal judgments that will befall them
vehicle: three emblematic agents of death: sword, famine, pestilence
ground: these three summarize the main covenant curses and so represent comprehensive destruction
representative parts standing for the entire range of disaster
posture: underscoring that no avenue of survival remains
instances.explanation: The recurring triad 'sword, famine, pestilence' is a stock synecdoche: these key calamities stand for the whole spectrum of covenant judgment, with 'sword' itself metonymic for warfare.

deliberation: Found two strong figurative expressions: (1) divine anger/wrath 'poured out' as if liquid, and (2) 'you will be an execration, horror, curse, and reproach,' where the people 'become' curse-formulas and objects of derision, a metaphor-metonymy for their future reputation.

instances.hebrew_text: כַּאֲשֶׁר נִתַּךְ אַפִּי וַחֲמָתִי עַל־יֹשְׁבֵי יְר֣וּשָׁלִַם כֵּן תִּתַּךְ חֲמָתִי עֲלֵיכֶם
instances.english_text: As My anger and wrath were poured out upon the inhabitants of Jerusalem, so will My wrath be poured out on you
target: the intensity and extent of God's punitive action
vehicle: liquid being poured out from a container
ground: both a poured liquid and unleashed wrath spread over and overwhelm what they fall upon
posture: warning them by analogy with past catastrophe
instances.explanation: God's wrath is pictured as a liquid that can be 'poured out' on people, a concrete metaphor that conveys the overwhelming and inescapable nature of His judgment.

instances.english_text: You shall become an execration, a horror, a curse, and a reproach
target: how other nations will speak and think about Judah
vehicle: verbal formulas of cursing, horror, and reproach
ground: becoming 'a curse' means being used as the content of curses and reproaches
being the negative example invoked in speech
posture: heightening the shame of their potential fate
instances.explanation: The people are said to 'become' an execration and a curse—that is, they will serve as the stock example in curses and taunts. This blends metaphor (becoming abstract speech-acts) with metonymy (their name standing in cursing formulas).

deliberation: Considered 'spoken against you' and 'testified against you.' The key figurative element is the Deuteronomistic formula 'I have testified against you today,' a legal metaphor framing God's warning as courtroom testimony.

instances.english_text: for I have testified against you this day
target: God's formal warning to the remnant
vehicle: a witness giving testimony in court
ground: both courtroom testimony and this prophetic warning create a formal record that leaves the hearers liable if they disregard it
posture: casting the warning in legal-covenantal terms
instances.explanation: God describes His prophetic warning as 'testifying' against them, treating the scene as a lawsuit in which He serves as a witness laying evidence on the record.

deliberation: The rebuke centers on self-deception. The phrase 'you have deceived yourselves' literally reads 'you have deceived in your souls,' where 'souls' (נְפָשׁוֹתֵיכֶם) stands metonymically for the persons themselves.

instances.english_text: you have deceived yourselves (lit. deceived in your souls)
target: the people themselves as responsible agents
ground: the 'soul' stands for the whole person, so misleading 'in your souls' means self-deception
metonymic use of a part/aspect for the whole person
posture: accusing them of willful inner dishonesty
instances.explanation: Here 'souls' functions metonymically for the people themselves, and the idiom conveys that they have acted as their own deceivers at the deepest level of selfhood.

deliberation: The main figurative element is the standard biblical idiom 'you did not hear in the voice of the LORD,' where 'hear' means 'obey' and 'voice' stands metonymically for the commandments themselves.

instances.english_text: you have not obeyed (listened to) the voice of the LORD your God
target: their failure to comply with God's commands
vehicle: not listening to the audible voice of a speaker
ground: both not listening to someone and not obeying them reject their authority and message
hearing as a prerequisite to and symbol for obedience
voice as the bearer of will/command
instances.explanation: The idiom uses 'hearing the voice' as a metaphor for obedience, with 'voice' standing metonymically for God’s revealed commands.

deliberation: As in v.17, the triad 'by the sword, by famine, and by pestilence' functions as a stock summary of covenant curses—representative synecdoche for comprehensive judgment. The final clause about the place they desire to go is literal.

instances.english_text: you shall die by the sword, by famine, and by pestilence
target: the comprehensive, lethal outcome awaiting them in Egypt
vehicle: three emblematic deadly agents: sword, famine, pestilence
ground: these three stand for the principal modes of covenant punishment and so imply total destruction
representative parts standing for the broader whole of disaster
instances.explanation: The repeated formula 'sword, famine, pestilence' uses metonymy (e.g., 'sword' for war) and functions as a synecdoche summarizing the whole range of fatal judgments to stress their completeness.
